channel.title: Reflection Explorer
channel.description:
Well, a few weeks of off and on work is finally done. Now to finish preparations for school.
[b]Runescape Reflection Explorer v1.0[/b]
Basically, we can use this handy dandy tool to reflect all the fields in the client at runtime. So, we can watch everything unfold as the client runs. By doing this, we can easily find out what values in the client do what, or find new fields which were never thought of before.
[b]Features:[/b]
[ul][li]Field filtering by value, name or type[/li] [li]Ability to compare fields with previous load, to find differences[/li] [li]Ability to rename fields[/li] [li]Can remove fields from the output, to remove "spam fields"[/li] [li]Easy to use interface keeps your work productive and easy[/li] [li]Can grab every index of single, and multidimensional primitive type arrays[/li][/ul]
[b]Known issues:[/b]
[ul][li]Currently, it can't reflect non static fields. The problem is, I realize I must create a new instance, but what am I to do when the class does not have a no-arg constructor to it?[/li] [li]Some fields duplicate themselves in the output. There is only a few to my knowledge, and I have no idea why. It is more of a cosmetic issue than a program issue. I am working on it however.[/li][/ul]
[b]Screenshot:[/b]
[URL=http://imageshack.us][IMG]http://img171.imageshack.us/img171/5882/80039746dt0.png[/img][/URL]
[b]Other info:[/b]
This is, to my knowledge, the second reflection explorer ever made. The first one was made by Ruler, and, to my knowledge, could only be used on the "client" class. It is also nexus dependent.
This explorer features a built in client loader. Now, I realize I will be criticized for this, so let me explain it. The loader sucks. Using this loader could very well get you banned. Treat this as a warning, PLEASE. I recommend using a throw away account with any cheating tool. On top of this, I am using a URL loader, but the program needs the runescape jar in the current directory. It is stupid, I know. Basically, the program parses the class names from the jar, then uses them for loading classes via the web. I will be changing it (probably tomorrow) to load from the jar.
Finding many fields with this tool is easy. For example, with the latest jar, the Login Index can easily be found by loading all the fields at the login screen and searching for the value of "10". From our results, we determine that the Login Index is ua.b.
Please post questions/comments/concerns.
Download: http://www.mediafire.com/?qdoy1ke4tg0 Source code is included. Binaries and source is also jar'd, but not tested.
EDIT:
[i]Update Thurs Aug 28: Fixed some errors and spelling mistakes from the initial release.[/i]

throw an error then, dont rely on assertions that may or may not be enabled

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

ephemeral:

Assertions should normally only be used when testing that the programs flow is correct

if control flow gets to the catch part, i would consider it a bug, ByteArrayInputStream never throws an IOException

try {
    xmlReader.parse(new InputSource(new ByteArrayInputStream(buffer)));
}
catch(IOException ex) {
    ex.printStackTrace();
    assert false;
}

if obj is null, i would consider it a bug.

synchronized(queueLock) {
    if(queue.isEmpty())
        queueLock.wait();
}

Something obj = queue.poll();
assert obj != null;
//do stuff with obj
frank_:

also assert should never be relied apon in live code

i never relied apon it.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Assertions should normally only be used when testing that the programs flow is correct, and have no bugs (similar to what frank_ said).

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’ve used assert in C before, didn’t even know you could do it in Java, however if it reaches that statement the error will print telling me what went wrong and how to fix it.

And what is ugly about the code? I tried to do it the most elegant way possible, criticisms don’t help very much if they aren’t followed by comments.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

assert only happens when you enable assertions, by default they are turned off

also assert should never be relied apon in live code

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Yz85Racer:

That’s fucking ugly code.

at least he uses the continue keyword now, i remember a time when he had if statements nested about 6 layers deep.

btw, for this bit,

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:228212”] } catch (Exception e) { //should never get here e.printStackTrace(); val = null; } [/quote]

instead of writing a comment, i prefer to use the assert keyword. it gives the same readability, but also enforces the rule in the language.

useful for byte array input streams i think.

try {
    xmlReader.parse(new InputSource(new ByteArrayInputStream(buffer)));
}
catch(IOException ex) {
    ex.printStackTrace();
    assert false;
}

i just like assert for saying “this should never happen”


synchronized(queueLock) {
    if(queue.isEmpty())
        queueLock.wait();
}

Something obj = queue.poll();
assert obj != null;
//do stuff with obj

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:228212”]I had a look at the code, and while it is good for looking at static variables in the runescape client, I decided to go ahead and write a generic one that will work for any class. This is command line only, but feel free to write a fancy GUI for it. I also haven’t implemented array support yet as it seems like something to be done at the users request in a GUI instead of printing lots of arrays out.

package com.cherokee.utils;

import java.lang.reflect.Field;
import java.lang.reflect.Modifier;

public class RuntimeViewer {

    public RuntimeViewer(Object o) {
        getFields(o);
    }

    private void getFields(Object o) {
        getFields(o.getClass().getName(), o.getClass(), o, "");
    }

    private void getFields(String name, Class klass, Object o, String tabs) {
        Field[] all = klass.getDeclaredFields();
        if(all.length == 0)
               System.out.println(tabs +"NO FIELDS FOUND!");
        for (Field f : all) {
            boolean isStatic = Modifier.isStatic(f.getModifiers());
            //if o is static, we can only look at static members of this class
            if(o == null && !isStatic)
                continue;
            System.out.print(tabs + (isStatic ? "static "+ klass.getName() : name)  + "." + f.getName()+" Type: "+f.getType().getName());
            Object val = getObject(f, o);
            // assures the value is primitive or a class provided by sun before displaying the value
            if (f.getType().isPrimitive() || (f.getType().getPackage() != null && f.getType().getPackage().getImplementationVendor() != null)){
                System.out.println(" Value: " + ((val == null) ? "null" : val.toString()));
            // if its another type, recurse on it to display it's values
            } else{
                System.out.println(" - ");
                  getFields(f.getName(), f.getType(), val, tabs+"\t");
            }
        }
    }

    private Object getObject(Field f, Object parent){
        boolean accessible = f.isAccessible();
        if (!accessible)
            f.setAccessible(true);

        Object val;
        try {
            val = f.get(parent);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            //should never get here
            e.printStackTrace();
            val = null;
        }

        if (!accessible)
            f.setAccessible(false);

        return val;
    }
}

Sample output on some test classes:

static Test1.rv Type: com.cherokee.utils.RuntimeViewer - 
	NO FIELDS FOUND!
Test1.intArray Type: [I - 
	NO FIELDS FOUND!
Test1.stringPubValTest Type: java.lang.String Value: Test
Test1.tt Type: Test2 - 
	tt.intPubVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	tt.intPubValNull Type: int Value: 0
	tt.stringPubValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	tt.stringPubValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	tt.intPrvVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	tt.intPrvValNull Type: int Value: 0
	tt.stringPrvValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	tt.stringPrvValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	static Test2.intPubStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPubStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPubStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPubStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	static Test2.intPrvStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPrvStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPrvStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPrvStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
Test1.tStaticNull Type: Test2 - 
	static Test2.intPubStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPubStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPubStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPubStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	static Test2.intPrvStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPrvStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPrvStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPrvStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
Test1.intPubVal10 Type: int Value: 10
Test1.intPubValNull Type: int Value: 0
Test1.stringPubValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
Test1.stringPubValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
Test1.intPrvVal10 Type: int Value: 10
Test1.intPrvValNull Type: int Value: 0
Test1.stringPrvValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
Test1.stringPrvValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
static Test1.intPubStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
static Test1.intPubStValNull Type: int Value: 0
static Test1.stringPubStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
static Test1.stringPubStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
static Test1.intPrvStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
static Test1.intPrvStValNull Type: int Value: 0
static Test1.stringPrvStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
static Test1.stringPrvStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null

I whipped up a quick cherokee script that makes it work too, but a GUI would make it much better as said above.

If you want this whole thing with the script and all ready to run, just check out the latest revision of cherokee from the sourceforge svn: http://sourceforge.net/svn/?group_id=182122

As always, comments/questions/criticisms are valued.[/quote]
That’s fucking ugly code.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I had a look at the code, and while it is good for looking at static variables in the runescape client, I decided to go ahead and write a generic one that will work for any class. This is command line only, but feel free to write a fancy GUI for it. I also haven’t implemented array support yet as it seems like something to be done at the users request in a GUI instead of printing lots of arrays out.

package com.cherokee.utils;

import java.lang.reflect.Field;
import java.lang.reflect.Modifier;

public class RuntimeViewer {

    public RuntimeViewer(Object o) {
        getFields(o);
    }

    private void getFields(Object o) {
        getFields(o.getClass().getName(), o.getClass(), o, "");
    }

    private void getFields(String name, Class klass, Object o, String tabs) {
        Field[] all = klass.getDeclaredFields();
        if(all.length == 0)
               System.out.println(tabs +"NO FIELDS FOUND!");
        for (Field f : all) {
            boolean isStatic = Modifier.isStatic(f.getModifiers());
            //if o is static, we can only look at static members of this class
            if(o == null && !isStatic)
                continue;
            System.out.print(tabs + (isStatic ? "static "+ klass.getName() : name)  + "." + f.getName()+" Type: "+f.getType().getName());
            Object val = getObject(f, o);
            // assures the value is primitive or a class provided by sun before displaying the value
            if (f.getType().isPrimitive() || (f.getType().getPackage() != null && f.getType().getPackage().getImplementationVendor() != null)){
                System.out.println(" Value: " + ((val == null) ? "null" : val.toString()));
            // if its another type, recurse on it to display it's values
            } else{
                System.out.println(" - ");
                  getFields(f.getName(), f.getType(), val, tabs+"\t");
            }
        }
    }

    private Object getObject(Field f, Object parent){
        boolean accessible = f.isAccessible();
        if (!accessible)
            f.setAccessible(true);

        Object val;
        try {
            val = f.get(parent);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            //should never get here
            e.printStackTrace();
            val = null;
        }

        if (!accessible)
            f.setAccessible(false);

        return val;
    }
}

Sample output on some test classes:

static Test1.rv Type: com.cherokee.utils.RuntimeViewer - 
	NO FIELDS FOUND!
Test1.intArray Type: [I - 
	NO FIELDS FOUND!
Test1.stringPubValTest Type: java.lang.String Value: Test
Test1.tt Type: Test2 - 
	tt.intPubVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	tt.intPubValNull Type: int Value: 0
	tt.stringPubValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	tt.stringPubValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	tt.intPrvVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	tt.intPrvValNull Type: int Value: 0
	tt.stringPrvValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	tt.stringPrvValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	static Test2.intPubStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPubStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPubStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPubStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	static Test2.intPrvStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPrvStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPrvStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPrvStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
Test1.tStaticNull Type: Test2 - 
	static Test2.intPubStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPubStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPubStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPubStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
	static Test2.intPrvStVal10 Type: int Value: 10
	static Test2.intPrvStValNull Type: int Value: 0
	static Test2.stringPrvStValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello
	static Test2.stringPrvStValNull Type: java.lang.String Value: null
Test1.intPubVal10 Type: int Value: 10
Test1.intPubValNull Type: int Value: 0
Test1.stringPubValHello Type: java.lang.String Value: Hello

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:8, topic:228212”]The source of this makes my brain bleed.

Still its seems to work.[/quote]Please elaborate.

Also, I kinda made a mistake in this one. You see, when i added multidimensional array support, it messed up the single array support. I have fixed it, and im uploading the latest version now.

I have also started work on adding a filter ability for the results you get when you compare fields. And also adding support for members worlds.

Another update I plan on doing is the ability to load/save “project” files. Basically, it will load/save a file containing all the fields you chose to remove/rename and will display the results from the last load.

This way, if you finish removing all the “spam” fields from the client, and you have a power outage, you can just load your last save. This will also allow myself, or someone else, to upload project files with renamed variables to help you explore and understand what is going on.

And of course, taking top priority, I’m almost done with non-static fields.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @cartridges cartridges
item.description:
@cartridges wrote:

What an interesting concept… I never once thought about doing something like this… But I suppose it would be an interesting means of monitoring variables and seeing how they correlate to in game changes.

Of course a java debugger has far less overhead and can do the exact same thing… Err, more really, you can set breakpoints and step through the bytecode too.

Eh, jdb is great, so is jprofiler… Static analysis can only go so far so fast we are human after all!

It’s prudent to explore all avenues of aquiring ones’ goals before setting out to spawn our own.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Explorer
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

Well, a few weeks of off and on work is finally done. Now to finish preparations for school.

Runescape Reflection Explorer v1.0

Basically, we can use this handy dandy tool to reflect all the fields in the client at runtime. So, we can watch everything unfold as the client runs. By doing this, we can easily find out what values in the client do what, or find new fields which were never thought of before.

Features:

[ul][li]Field filtering by value, name or type[/li]
[li]Ability to compare fields with previous load, to find differences[/li]
[li]Ability to rename fields[/li]
[li]Can remove fields from the output, to remove “spam fields”[/li]
[li]Easy to use interface keeps your work productive and easy[/li]
[li]Can grab every index of single, and multidimensional primitive type arrays[/li][/ul]

Known issues:

[ul][li]Currently, it can’t reflect non static fields. The problem is, I realize I must create a new instance, but what am I to do when the class does not have a no-arg constructor to it?[/li]
[li]Some fields duplicate themselves in the output. There is only a few to my knowledge, and I have no idea why. It is more of a cosmetic issue than a program issue. I am working on it however.[/li][/ul]

Screenshot:

Other info:

This is, to my knowledge, the second reflection explorer ever made. The first one was made by Ruler, and, to my knowledge, could only be used on the “client” class. It is also nexus dependent.

This explorer features a built in client loader. Now, I realize I will be criticized for this, so let me explain it. The loader sucks. Using this loader could very well get you banned. Treat this as a warning, PLEASE. I recommend using a throw away account with any cheating tool. On top of this, I am using a URL loader, but the program needs the runescape jar in the current directory. It is stupid, I know. Basically, the program parses the class names from the jar, then uses them for loading classes via the web. I will be changing it (probably tomorrow) to load from the jar.

Finding many fields with this tool is easy. For example, with the latest jar, the Login Index can easily be found by loading all the fields at the login screen and searching for the value of “10”. From our results, we determine that the Login Index is ua.b.

Please post questions/comments/concerns.

Download:
http://www.mediafire.com/?qdoy1ke4tg0
Source code is included. Binaries and source is also jar’d, but not tested.

EDIT:

Update Thurs Aug 28: Fixed some errors and spelling mistakes from the initial release.

Read full topic
